body:
Welcome to your introductory course on upskilling. 


In today's modern workplace, we are seeing increasing numbers of employees with a desire to improve and grow their skillsets. In fact, the ability to provide learning opportunities to employees has become a factor that 90% of full-time workers consider very important when searching for a new job (Amdocs 2021). This process of training employees on different skills is knows as upskilling.


This course will dive deeper into the importance of upskilling and how you can begin to implement it within your workforce!


In this course, you can expect to learn:

  • The definition of upskilling vs. reskilling
  • Why upskilling is beneficial to you and your team
  • The step-by-step process of upskilling
  • Examples of how to introduce upskilling in the workplace
title: Text Title

body:
Let's begin by digging deeper into what we mean when we use the term upskilling. 


There is another variation of upskilling that you may see throughout this course, and that is called reskilling. But don't worry, we'll be sure to cover that as well before we move forward.

_items.backText:
- Learning/teaching additional skills that are related to a current position

- Prepares an employee to be better equipped in their role

- Does not typically involve a change in career

- Ex: Training a Sales Specialist how to use online conferencing tools to meet with customers virtually

- Learning/teaching new skills that are not related to a current position

- Prepares an employee to perform a different role

- Typically involves a change in career

- Ex: Providing graphic design training to a Customer Service Representative so that they can move into a UX Designer role

_items.title: Fill Skill Gaps & Workplace Needs
_items.body:
Upskilling prepares employees to fill open roles and workplace needs, while also presenting opportunities for valued existing employees to take on new roles and functions. By regularly upskilling the workforce, employers improve specific skillets and encourage the ability to adapt to change. Skills are only skills if they can adapt to the changes of time!


Upskilling soft skills? You're building leaders. 

Technical competencies? You're developing a workforce that is prepared for industry changes.

_items.title: Increase Collaboration
_items.body:
Both upskilling and reskilling often involve hands-on techniques such as job shadowing, cross-departmental collaboration, and collaborative learning. As a result, organizations see stronger teams and strengthened shared goals. 


Upskilling and reskilling also require leaders to be on the same page about their goals, strategies, and policies. This collaboration builds consistency in organizational values and methods around workplace planning and skill development.

When it comes to the effects of upskilling on retention and job satisfaction, the statistics speak for themselves. 


Upskilling produces an increase in productivity and engagement of employees. 8 out of 10 employees report increased job satisfaction due to upskilling. Companies see the same results, with 91% of companies reporting an increase in employee productivity due to upskilling. 


In a survey of full-time workers across the U.S., nearly two-thirds (64%) of employees stated that they would leave their jobs due to a lack of growth and training opportunities. By staying ahead of the game and embedding upskilling into your company culture, you can anticipate employees' desire for growth and prevent future struggles with retention!
_items.title: Improve Retention & Job Satisfaction

_items.body:
As we discussed in the previous tab, employees who engage in upskilling and reskilling experience higher levels of engagement and retention. When retention increased, the need to hire new employees or fill vacancies decreases. 


According to Gallup, the cost of replacing a salaried employee can range from one-half to two times the employee’s annual salary. Think of the costs your organization could save by upskilling current employees instead of paying to train new hires!
_items.title: Decrease Hiring Costs

_items.body:
Upskilling communicates that you are a company who rewards and values its employees. Building this type of reputation and culture is invaluable in today's modern workplace. 


Once you've established a culture of growth, your reputation will build itself. Employees who have experienced the benefits of continuous training and development are often enthusiastic and more than willing to share their experiences to potential new hires. Research shows that 91% of millennials prefer career development to any other benefit when choosing a new employer. 


Building a culture of upskilling employees will help you source new talent and stay one step ahead of your competition.

_items.body:
Before you can move forward onto any further steps, you must first identify your organization's current needs and your team member's current skills. 


To assess your organization's current needs, be sure to ask yourself, managers, and individuals contributors:


- What skills do we value as a company?

- What skills do our employees need to do their jobs well now and in the next 1-3 years?

- Consider your company’s job descriptions, business objectives and company values. What new skills might your company need in coming years?


It is extremely important to survey different team members on what the organization needs. Their insights could prove invaluable and involving your employees can help them feel that they’re contributing to your company’s growth, which improves peer collaboration. 

Now on to assessing current skills of employees. This will provide an accurate starting point, so that both you and your employees will know where they’re starting from and can measure progress as you develop new skills.


To assess your employees' current skills, it may be helpful to review:


- Pulse surveys and engagement surveys

- Interviews with employees

- Feedback from performance reviews
_items.title: Conduct a Skills Analysis

_items.body:
Now that you have an understanding of what employees need and what the organization needs, it's time to set goals.


This process begins with asking your employees about their goals. Where do they see themselves in one year? What skills do they want to develop?


Once you have individual goals, you can tie those goals to team and company goals. When employees understand how their work contributes to organizational growth, it serves as a significant motivator. Think about it. Which situation inspires you more?

1. Improve your communication skills

2.  Improve your communication skills, which will improve team rapport with future customers and expand the company's market to 10 additional states by 2022.


Option #2, which ties an employee goal to a team goal to an organizational goal, is much more engaging and motivating!


As managers set goals with their team members, each goal should be tied to at least one of the company’s strategic objectives. The goal should also be measurable.


Don't forget to include deadlines. Time parameters increase motivation and boost morale, making them essential to the goal setting process! Without deadlines, goals lack structure and purpose. At the same time, it’s important to strike a balance between a sense of urgency and unrealistic timelines that are impossible for employees to achieve.
_items.title: Set Collaborative Goals

_items.body:
Identify how the previously set goals will help employees to learn new skills, and find ways to link the goals to their career growth.


There are many methods to support an employee in upskilling. For now, let's break those methods down into two categories.


1. Hands-on Training

- Coaching: This method can be broken down into 3 steps - I do, We do, You do. First, set aside time to observe an employee demonstrating their skill. Then show them how you would demonstrate that same skill. Second, provide the employee with an opportunity to practice the skill while you provide feedback. Lastly, allow the employee to attempt the skill independently. 

- Mentoring: Partner the employee with a more experienced peer to learn how they have developed strength with the skill. This can include shadowing, weekly check-ins, or even a coaching session using "I do, We do, You do." Be sure to set boundaries around the mentorship to prevent burnout of the more experienced peer!

- Stretch assignments: A stretch assignment is a project or task that is currently beyond an employee's level of knowledge or skill. These projects develop employee competencies and confidence, while also providing data for future career succession plans. For example, let's take a Customer Service Representative who is currently in school for Graphic Design. This employee may benefit from a low-risk UX Design assignment, such as taking customer feedback around a new product and presenting findings and a prototype solution to the UX Design team. 


2. Traditional Training

- Learning Management System: Reference your LMS or LXP for available trainings that may support the employee in developing skills. If you don't see the training, reach out to your Learning & Development department. They may be able to create a training for this need!

- Allocate paid training time: Allow employees to carve out time in their work day to complete trainings. This serves as a way to reward employees for initiating skill development, as they are getting paid to train.

- Case studies: Provide employees with a case study that related to their skill of focus. Learning from case studies allows employees to see the immediate benefit. If you want to expand, engage in discussion with the employee after they have read the case study. You can even assess an employee's knowledge retention after reading the case study by setting up a roleplaying situation, such as one between a customer service representative and a customer. 


Remember, you can get creative! This list is not exhaustive, and there are hundreds of methods that you can use to upskill your employees. Do what works for your team, your bandwidth of time and energy, and the goals of your situation.
_items.title: Develop a Path to Learning

_items.body:
Last but certainly not least, track and measure progress. Remember, your goal should be measurable and tied to a qualitative or quantitative metric. Clarity about goal measurement helps everyone stay on the same page about when a target has been met. 


Check in with your employee at least once per week to discuss progress towards their goal. Research shows that 85% of employees say they’re most motivated when management offers regular updates


Monitoring goal progress also allows you to recognize wins. When the company, team, or individual accomplishes a goal, it’s time to celebrate! research found that when employees believe they will be recognized, they are 2.7x more likely to be highly engaged. Recognizing goal achievement demonstrates to all employees that the organization values and appreciates their efforts. This serves to incentivize and inspire everyone to continue developing the goals that will move the organization forward.
